Short internal checklist — verifying basic astronomy claims for exhibit labels

1) Quick classification
- Read the claim and decide if it’s:
  a) Simple factual (e.g., “Which planet is largest?”)
  b) Measurement/quantitative (e.g., distance, mass, age)
  c) Interpretive/controversial (e.g., “first life detected”, habitability)
- If (a) or simple (b), proceed with checklist. If (c) or uncertain, escalate (see below).

2) Basic verification steps (for simple factual claims)
- Identify the exact quantity/definition the label uses (e.g., “largest by volume”, “most massive”, “largest planet” — clarify metric).
- Check at least two independent, reputable sources that explicitly support the claim.
- Confirm units, epoch/date, and whether counts change over time (e.g., moon counts).
- Note the source(s), page/URL, and date accessed on the label review log.

3) Acceptable sources (use these first)
- Space agencies and mission pages: NASA (Solar System Exploration, Planetary Fact Sheet), JPL, ESA.
- Established observatories and institutions: Arecibo/NOAO/Caltech/Harvard-Smithsonian (where relevant).
- Curated data services: NASA Planetary Data System, JPL Solar System Dynamics (planetary and satellite lists), SIMBAD for objects, ADS for papers.
- Professional body positions: International Astronomical Union (IAU) statements for definitions/nomenclature.
- Textbooks and peer‑reviewed literature for definitions and contested/technical issues.
- NOTE: Wikipedia is acceptable as a starting check only — always verify with a primary/official source cited above.

4) Common quick-check examples
- “Which planet is largest?” — clarify metric (by volume/mass). Verify with NASA/JPL planetary facts.
- “Which planet has the most moons?” — moon counts change; cite JPL or NASA counts and date.
- “Oldest star/galaxy” or cosmological ages — rely on peer‑reviewed literature and clarify uncertainties.

5) Red flags that require escalation
Escalate to the curator or science reviewer (astronomer/subject-matter expert) when any of the following apply:
- Claim is ambiguous about the metric (mass vs volume vs diameter).
- Data are time-sensitive or recently changed (moon counts, newly discovered exoplanets, transient discoveries).
- Conflicting reputable sources (e.g., source A says X, source B says Y).
- Claim depends on preliminary results or preprints not yet peer-reviewed.
- Statement involves interpretation, implications, or controversy (e.g., “life on X”, origins, dark matter/dark energy explanations).
- Units, conversions, or large-number notation could cause misinterpretation.
- Cultural/historical claims about observations requiring sensitivity or contextual accuracy.

6) Escalation procedure
- Log the issue (claim, sources checked, why it’s escalated).
- Notify: exhibit curator + designated science reviewer (internal) within 24 hours.
- If internal reviewer cannot resolve within 48 hours, seek external expert (university astronomer or agency scientist) or consult recent peer-reviewed literature; document correspondence and final source.
- Record final decision, exact wording to use, and citation in the review log before printing or publishing.

7) Documentation & version control
- Keep a one-line source citation and access date on the label proof or in the exhibit file.
- Add reviewer initials and date for every verified claim.
- Recheck time-sensitive claims annually or when major related discoveries are publicized.

Quick template to fill when verifying a claim
- Claim:
- Metric/definition clarified:
- Sources checked (2+): (source, URL, date)
- Result (OK / needs revision / escalated):
- Reviewer initials & date:
- If escalated: person contacted & date, resolution summary:

Use this checklist as the default workflow for all astronomy labels. For recurring or high‑profile exhibits, schedule periodic expert reviews beyond the basic checklist.

text: I'm writing a kids' book about Jupiter being the biggest planet. Should I add any caveats or qualifiers, or just state it directly?
proposition: Jupiter is the largest planet in our solar system.
response_text:
Short answer: say it directly, but add one simple, age‑appropriate caveat so the statement is accurate and doesn’t create misunderstandings.

Why: children respond well to clear, bold facts. “Jupiter is the biggest planet” is a great main line. A tiny extra note prevents confusion (e.g., thinking Jupiter is the biggest thing in space) and gives a chance to teach scale.

Suggested approaches and sample text by age:

- Toddlers (2–5): simple, bold line + a tiny fact
  - Main line: “Jupiter is the biggest planet.”
  - Quick caveat: “The Sun is even bigger.”  
- Early readers (6–8): main line + a playful comparison
  - Main line: “Jupiter is the biggest planet in our Solar System.”
  - Add: “It’s so big you could fit more than 1,300 Earths inside it!”  
- Older kids (9–12): one precise main line + short scientific caveat
  - Main line: “Jupiter is the largest planet in our Solar System by diameter, mass, and volume.”
  - Caveat: “Some planets found around other stars (called exoplanets) can be as big or bigger than Jupiter, and the Sun is far bigger than any planet.”

Extra quick tips:
- Keep the caveat short and visually separate (a small sidebar, a speech bubble, or a single extra sentence) so it doesn’t disrupt the main story flow.
- Use concrete visuals/analogies (e.g., “If Earth were a grape, Jupiter would be a basketball”) to help kids grasp scale.

response_text:
Title
Jupiter — the Solar System’s Giant

Subtitle
Bigger than all the other planets combined. Fast, fierce, and full of surprises.

Quick facts (short, bold lines)
- Diameter: 139,820 km — about 11× Earth across
- Mass: 1.90 × 10^27 kg — ~318 Earth masses
- Volume: can hold ~1,321 Earths
- Day: ~9 hours 55 minutes (fastest spin of any planet)
- Orbit: 11.86 Earth years, ~5.2 AU from the Sun
- Moons: 95 known (as of 2023)
- Composition: mostly hydrogen and helium

What makes it the largest?
Jupiter formed early and gathered enormous amounts of gas and ice. Its huge mass dominates the outer solar system — in fact, it contains more than twice the mass of all the other planets combined and has shaped the orbits of many nearby objects.

A turbulent atmosphere
Banding of clouds, powerful jet streams, and storms create Jupiter’s striped appearance. The Great Red Spot — a long-lived storm larger than Earth — is the planet’s most famous feature.

Extreme rotation and shape
Jupiter’s rapid spin flattens it into an oblate shape: the equator bulges outward. That same spin powers fierce winds that can exceed hundreds of kilometers per hour.

Moons, rings and magnetic might
Jupiter hosts a large system of moons (from tiny captured rocks to the ocean-world Europa) and faint rings. Its magnetic field is the strongest of any planet in the solar system, producing intense radiation belts.

Why Jupiter matters
Jupiter’s gravity helped sculpt the solar system — influencing asteroid and comet paths and protecting (and sometimes redirecting) smaller bodies. Studying Jupiter helps us understand giant planets around other stars and conditions for planetary systems to form.

Did you know?
- Jupiter’s magnetic tail stretches millions of kilometers — past Saturn’s orbit.
- Europa, one of Jupiter’s moons, likely hides a global subsurface ocean and is a prime target in the search for life.
- If you could drop Earth into Jupiter, our planet would be roughly the size of a single cloud feature.

Suggested microcopy for visuals
- Size comparison: “11 Earths across”
- Mass comparison: “318× Earth’s mass”
- Atmosphere label: “Hydrogen + Helium — with stormy bands”
- Great Red Spot callout: “Storm bigger than Earth”
